item.title: Using Drafts and Hook
item.dc:creator: RochelleB-S
item.description:
I use Drafts daily, with the intention of it being “where text starts.” Often, I have a document stored elsewhere (Microsoft Word, Evernote, Todoist, etc.) that I want to be adding notes to. But, because I’m so used to starting text in Drafts, it’s instinctive to go to Drafts. Rather then end up starting a new Draft or fruitlessly searching Drafts for documents that are elsewhere, I create a Hook link to the “document stored elsewhere” and create a Draft that just contains the link.

Here’s a specific use case: I’m an editor and writer. I have weekly catch-up meeting with a client, during which she gives me updates about the company’s 8 or so different industry groups, talks about potential future articles I might write for those groups, updates me on the quarter’s marketing priorities, etc. She often repeats the same information from meeting to meeting. For me to best reference it, this information should be in one Microsoft Word document, organized by industry group, in outline form. But, muscle memory keeps sending me to write in Drafts. I used to wind up with multiple Drafts about this client, all of which I’d have to open up and synthesize. Now, I have one Draft that contains only a Hook link to the Microsoft Word document. When I open Drafts and search for the client name, that Draft comes up. I click the link, which opens my Word doc, and I’m ready to go.

item.title: Using Drafts and Hook
item.dc:creator: sylumer
item.description:
I have Hook and Drafts, but most of my Drafts content is transient or transactional for particular processes. As such i’ve simply never had need to link to anything in Drafts with it. However, it would seem a good way to cross link across your system if Drafts stores any persistent information for your PKM system.

I’m not sure there’s much to say about it specifically in regards to Drafts though as Hook acts like a meta framework above apps to deep link them together.

If you like Zettelkasten as an approach but would like to work across multiple apps, Hook has you covered. If you are all in on Drafts, the app will suffice with its own functionality.
